abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome of the Agricultural
            Sector Investment (ASIL) Project is rated as satisfactory.
            The lessons learned from this project include: 1) The most
            critical determinant of the success of this project can be
            attributed in a large part to government commitment and the
            strength of the Bank-Government partnership and policy
            dialogue. 2) Overall, the ASIL was designed to strengthen
            the Regional Commissariat for Agricultural Development
            (CRDA) capacity to run an investment budget, and to
            strengthen the Ministry of Agriculture in the center to
            prioritize/monitor/arbitrate the investment budgets proposed
            by the CRDAs at the aggregate level. This requires a high
            degree of coordination. 3) The Borrower's financial and
            procurement procedures need to be simplified. 4) The
            Government emphasized the priority that they gave to having
            the ASIL already in place at the beginning of their 1994
            budget year and the Bank was responsive in accelerating the
            processing timetable to accommodate this demand. However,
            this complex multi-component project would have benefited
            from more preparation time, taking into account the large
            number of sub-projects and the time consuming nature of the
            procurement and contracting procedures. 5) The follow up
            project and the initiation of detailed preparation studies
            on other key sub-sectors resulted in new operations that
            deepened and strengthened the reforms initiated through this project.
